entries.title: General applicability — FMCSA safety regulations
entries.summary: Defines when the FMCSA safety regulations (Parts 390–399) apply. Generally applies to commercial motor vehicles engaged in interstate commerce or specific intrastate commercial activities, not to ordinary non-commercial private passenger vehicles.
entries.on_mission_conditions: Applied to drivers and motor carriers operating commercial motor vehicles (CMVs) as defined in 49 CFR 390.5, in covered commercial activities.
entries.off_mission_signals: Used as justification to stop, detain, ticket, or process non-commercial private citizens in ordinary passenger vehicles, who are not operating CMVs within the FMCSA definitions.
entries.funding_on_mission_example: Roadside inspections of interstate CMV operators subject to hours-of-service, drug and alcohol testing, and other FMCSR provisions.
entries.funding_off_mission_example: Using CMV-focused enforcement units or MCSAP-funded patrol to stop and ticket non-commercial private drivers for general traffic violations unrelated to CMV safety.
entries.notes_for_engine: CDA can map flags 'scope_noncommercial_treated_as_commercial' and 'preemption_conflict' to this authority where states extend FMCSR-based enforcement to non-commercial citizens.

entries.title: Definitions — Commercial Motor Vehicle (CMV)
entries.summary: Provides the definition of 'commercial motor vehicle' for purposes of FMCSA safety regulations, typically based on weight, passenger capacity, or hazardous materials, and tied to commercial use.
entries.on_mission_conditions: Enforcement limited to vehicles and operations meeting the regulatory CMV definitions (e.g., weight thresholds, passenger capacity, hazardous materials, business/commercial use).
entries.off_mission_signals: Treating any privately owned passenger car used for ordinary personal travel as a 'CMV' solely because it is on a public roadway.
entries.funding_on_mission_example: Inspections and enforcement actions targeting CMV operators in regulated commercial service.
entries.funding_off_mission_example: Using CMV-focused funding, personnel, or infrastructure primarily to enforce general state traffic codes on non-commercial private vehicles.
entries.notes_for_engine: CDA/CFF can use this to determine whether a given enforcement scenario involves a CMV as defined or an off-scope private citizen.

entries.title: MCSAP — What conditions must a State meet to qualify for MCSAP funds?
entries.summary: Defines compatibility requirements for States to receive MCSAP funding, including adopting and enforcing safety regulations applicable to commercial motor vehicles and drivers.
entries.on_mission_conditions: State adopts and enforces laws/regulations that are compatible with federal FMCSRs for CMVs and commercial drivers as defined.
entries.off_mission_signals: State uses MCSAP-funded enforcement to police non-commercial drivers, private vehicles not defined as CMVs, or general criminal code unrelated to CMV safety.
entries.funding_on_mission_example: Commercial vehicle safety inspections, CMV crash reduction programs, enforcement directly tied to FMCSR compliance.
entries.funding_off_mission_example: Spending MCSAP grant funds on routine patrols that primarily issue citations to non-commercial drivers (e.g., seatbelt, minor speeding, license status) not tied to CMVs or FMCSR scope.
entries.notes_for_engine: CFF can use this as a rule to classify line items as OFF_MISSION when spend is clearly directed to broad, non-CMV traffic enforcement.
